metadata.case_name: Jagat Dhish Bhargava v. Jawahar Lal Bhargava & Ors.

facts.text: Agreement of sale of one third of the one fourth share in the property entered into between Gokal Dhish Bhargava and the appellant Jagat Dhish Bhargava.
Gokal Dhish Bhargava sued the appellant and pro forma respondents 8 and 9 for specific performance in Civil Suit No. 684/128 of 1949/50 in the Court of the Senior Civil Judge, New Delhi.
Pending decision in trial court, Gokal Dhish Bhargava died and his son Jawahar Lal Bhargava (respondent 1) and Chunni Lal Bhargava were brought on record as legal representatives.
After suit dismissal and before appeal, Chunni Lal Bhargava died; respondents 2 to 7 as his legal representatives joined respondent 1 in preferring appeal in High Court of Punjab.
Memo of appeal along with judgment dismissing suit and taxed bill of costs filed in High Court on July 29, 1954.
On March 24, 1954, respondents 2 to 7 applied for certified copy of judgment and decree; certified copy of judgment and bill of costs supplied, but no decree drawn up so no copy supplied.
On August 2, 1954, Assistant Registrar returned memo of appeal as defective without copy of decree.
On August 16, 1954, respondents refiled appeal with endorsement that only memo of costs prepared, no decree drawn up.
Appeal registered as No. 77-D of 1954; admitted by Dulat, J. on August 30, 1954 under O. 41, r. 11.
Appeal placed for hearing on December 26, 1958 before Circuit Bench.
On December 23, 1958, appellant served notice on respondents' counsel raising preliminary objection on competence due to no decree filed.
On December 24, 1958, respondents moved trial court for drawing up decree, but infructuous as record sent to High Court.
On December 29, 1958, respondents moved High Court to declare appeal maintainable or send record for decree.
Appeal heard on December 8, 1959 before Falshaw and Chopra, JJ.; preliminary objection overruled, time given to get decree drawn up.
High Court order dated December 15, 1959 sending record back to lower court.
Subsequent to High Court order, respondents obtained certified copy of decree on December 23, 1959 and filed it in High Court.
Present appeal by special leave against High Court order dated December 15, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal preferred against the appellant and respondents 8 and 9 in the High Court of Punjab by respondents 2 to 7 was competent in law without a copy of the decree as required under O. 41, r. 1 CPC.
Whether the time taken for drawing up the decree after application for certified copy should be excluded under s. 12(2) Limitation Act for computing limitation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal filed before High Court plainly incompetent as no copy of decree filed with memo of appeal; O. 41, r. 1 mandatory, appeal must be dismissed.
Application on March 24, 1954 was only for judgment and bill of costs, not decree; respondents should have moved trial court earlier for drawing up decree.

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal should be declared maintainable as memo of costs with concluding paragraph of judgment satisfies decree requirements; alternatively, allow time to get decree drawn up.

court_reasoning.text: O. 41, r. 1 requires copy of decree and judgment; cannot dispense with decree; appeal against decree, limitation from decree date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requirements of O. 41, r. 1 mandatory; absence of decree makes filing incomplete.

court_reasoning.text: Trial court office negligent in not drawing up decree; High Court office overlooked defect at admission stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Litigant not at fault; applied for copies bona fide.

court_reasoning.text: Under s. 12(2) Limitation Act, time for obtaining certified copy includes time for drawing up decree if applied before drawn up; appeal filed on Dec 23, 1959 in time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Whole period from application date to decree signing excluded.

court_reasoning.text: No hard and fast rule; scrutinize at initial stage, adjourn if necessary, direct lower court to draw decree; unfair to penalize for court office default.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act of court shall not injure suitor.

holdings.text: Appeal in High Court competent and in time upon filing certified copy of decree on Dec 23, 1959; High Court order allowing time fair and just.
Time requisite for certified copy under s. 12(2) Limitation Act includes time for drawing up decree where application made before decree drawn.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Requirements for preferring appeal with decree and judgment copies; procedure for drawing up decree after judgment.

statutes_cited.relevance: Exclusion of time for obtaining certified copy of decree, including drawing up; 90 days from decree date.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld High Court order allowing respondents time to file certified copy of decree, declared High Court appeal competent and in time, directed High Court to hear appeal on merits without re-admission under O.41 r.11.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court appeal to proceed on merits.

key_quotes.text: The short question of law which arises for decision in the present appeal by special leave is whether the appeal preferred against the appellant and respondents 8 and 9 in the High Court of Punjab by respondents 2 to 7 was competent in law.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In law the appeal is not so much against the judgment as against the decree that is why Article 156 of the Limitation Act prescribes a period of 90 days for such appeals and provides that the period commences to run from the date of the decree under appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes appeal is against decree, mandatory filing.

key_quotes.text: One of the first and highest duties of all Courts is to take care that the act of the Court does not injury to any of the suitors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle protecting litigant from court defaults.

key_quotes.text: No hard and fast rule of general applicability can be laid down for dealing with appeals defectively filed under O. 41, r. 1.
key_quotes.speaker: court
